msItem.note: Two leaves from a 14th-century Latin manuscript, containing Joshua 24:25–33 and Judges 2:6–12, both with a marginal gloss.

msItem.title: Genesis–Psalms in the Later Version of the Wycliffite Bible
msItem.note: Imperfect at the end because of the loss of quires (ends with a rubric for Proverbs). Starts with Jerome’s prefatory epistles in the Later Version of the Wycliffite Bible, Broþir ambrose bryngynge… and I haue take þe Epistlis… (fols. 3r–6r) (see Dove, M., The first English Bible: the text and context of the Wycliffite versions (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007), p. 199). the Later Version of the Wycliffite Bible prologues at Josua (At þe last whanne þe fyue bookes of moyses…), 1 Kings (The langage of men sirus & of caldeis also witnessiþ…) and 1 Chronicles (Iff þe makynge of þe seuenti interpretours dwelle… and The book of paralipomenon þat is þe bregging…) (see Dove, M., The first English Bible: the text and context of the Wycliffite versions (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007), pp. 200–1). The prologue to 1 Kings (fols. 115v–116v) follows its text; notes þe prolog of þe bookis of kingis stondiþ at þe ende of þis book (fol. 102r) and þis prolog shulde haue stonde bifore þis book (fol. 115v). the Earlier Version of the Wycliffite Bible prologues at the beginning of 2 Chronicles, 1 Ezra (Wheþir it be hardere to doon…; Esdras & nemye helpere… and þe comendacioun of Esdre), Tobit, Judith (Anentis þe ebrewis þe book…), Esther, Job (I am constreyned bi alle… and Iff forsoþe I shulde make a ionke[t] wiþ rusche…) and psalms (Whanne it is knowun alle þe profetis… and Dauiþ þe sone of gesse…) (see Dove, M., The first English Bible: the text and context of the Wycliffite versions (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007), pp. 201–2). See Forshall, J. and Madden, F. (eds), The Holy Bible … in the earliest English versions made from the Latin Vulgate by John Wycliffe and his followers, 4 vols (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1850), vol. 1, pp. xxix, on the relationship of New College MS. 66 to other copies that retain prologues in Old Testament. Notes in red on the differences between the Latin and Hebrew texts in Esther 9–16.

The scribe compressed the text to finish prologues to psalms on fol. 210v in order to start psalms on a new quire; there is no catchword on the page preceding the beginning of psalms. Rubric, Here bygynnyþ þe sauter þe which is red comynly in chirchis. Psalmus I. Psalms have titles in red, which include psalm numbers, and are laid out as prose with alternating plain 1-line red or blue initials at the beginnings of verses. There are textual divisions, marked with 4-line gold initials with floral sprays, at psalms 26, 38, 52, 68, 80, 97 and 109; other psalms and parts of psalm 118 start with 3-line initials. Psalm 118 is subdivided into 11-verse units at the beginning (aleph–daleth) and into 22-verse units afterwards. No Latin incipits, with the exception of those at some subdivisions in psalm 118. Note in red Comendacioun, probably in the hand of the original rubricator, at the beginning of psalm 118, referring to its use in the ‘Commendation of the Souls’.

Running titles in red, usually consisting of an abbreviated title of the book on the verso and chapter numbers as Roman numerals above each of the two columns on both rectos and versos. Usual rubrics in red. Chapter numbers in red, typically in the form cᵐ iiiᵐ. Many corrections in the original or contemporary hands in the margins, within the text and over erasures (some lengthy corrections are in Anglicana); some text is crossed out in red. Marginal glosses appear occasionally; added material within the text is consistently underlined in red throughout; lections are not marked. Red and blue paraphs within the text.

supportDesc.foliation: modern in pencil; two unnumbered flyleaves at the beginning + 1–236
supportDesc.collation: (fols. 1–2) two singletons | (fols. 3–234) I–XXIX (8) | (fols. 235–236) two singletons. Catchwords survive; quire signatures partially survive at the beginning, running consecutively +, a–d, etc. neþ & no man… (fol. 4r)

layoutDesc.layout: ruled for two columns, with single vertical and horizontal bounding lines extending the full height and width of page, and a single additional bounding line in the upper margin; 56–7 lines per page; written space: c. 240 155–160

decoDesc.decoNote: 4- to 6-line initials, decorated with foliage on gold background and threequarters borders made of gold, blue and pink bars, decorated with foliage and gold disks at the beginnings of books. Simpler decoration with floral sprays, rather than borders, at Ruth (fol. 106v), 2 Kings (fol. 116v), 3 Kings (fol. 127r), 4 Kings (fol. 139v), 2 Ezra (fol. 181r), Tobit (fol. 187r), Esther (fol. 195v) and Job (fol. 201r).
3- to 4-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of prologues; 2- to 3-line similar initials at the beginnings of chapters.

binding.p:
Brown leather, 17th century, over wood boards from a medieval (?) binding. Blind fillet-line border round the outer edge of both covers. Rectangular blind fillet-line and blind roll decoration on both covers. Rebacked with the original spine relaid. Six raised bands on spine. Fragmentary paper label on spine with handwritten ‘MS.
New Coll.
…’. Fittings of two clasps, now lost, on both covers. Leaves from a 13th-century manuscript used as flyleaves at the front and back.

origin.p:
Dialect survey:
ony(10), ech(8)/eech(1)/eche(1), fier(8)/fir(1)/fyer(1), ȝoue(6)/ȝouun(3), lijf(10), lijk(10), myche(9)/moche(1), siȝ(9) (sg.), sien(6) (pl.), silf(9)/sylf(1), siche(2)/ sich(2), þorou(3)/þorouȝ(1)
-iþ(7)/-yþ(1)/-eþ(2) (pres.ind.3sg.), -en(10) (pres.ind.pl.), -ynge(7)/-yng(1)/inge(1) (pres.part.), sche(5)/she(5) (3sg.fem.pronoun, nom.), þei(10) (3pl. pronoun, nom.), hem(10) (3pl.pronoun, oblique), her(10) (3pl.pronoun, possessive)

history.provenance: Notes on the subject matter of several chapters of Deuteronomy added in a late 15th-century hand on the second unnumbered flyleaf at the beginning.

recordHist.source: Elizabeth Solopova, Manuscripts of the Wycliffite Bible in the Bodleian and Oxford College Libraries, Exeter Medieval Texts and Studies (Liverpool: Liverpool University Press, 2016), no. 56.

listBibl.bibl: Forshall, J. and Madden, F. (eds), The Holy Bible … in the earliest English versions made from the Latin Vulgate by John Wycliffe and his followers, 4 vols (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1850), vol. 1, pp. xxix, xxxiv, xxxv, lii; sigla O – prologues from Genesis to 1 Chronicles; K – prologue to 1 Ezra; O – prologues from 2 Chronicles to Psalter, except that to 1 Ezra.
Coxe, H. O., Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque Oxoniensibus hodie adservantur, 2 vols (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1852), vol. 1, Catalogus codicum MSS. Collegii Novi, p. 19.
Ogilvie-Thomson, S. J., Index of Middle English prose, 18 vols (Cambridge, 1984– ), Handlist VIII (1991), p. 54.
Dove, M., The first English Bible: the text and context of the Wycliffite versions (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007), pp. 18, 94, 96, 98, 100, 138, 141, 156, 199, 200–2, 217, 228, 239.
